document.docTitle: Ophiozonella cavernalis Okanishi & Fujita 2018, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: First finding of anchialine and submarine cave dwelling brittle stars from the Pacific Ocean, with descriptions of new species of Ophiolepis and Ophiozonella (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea: Amphilepidida)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First finding of anchialine and submarine cave dwelling brittle stars from the Pacific Ocean, with descriptions of new species of Ophiolepis and Ophiozonella (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea: Amphilepidida)

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type material.
Holotype : RUMF-ZE-02008, submarine cave ( Hedo-Dome cave) on northern Okinawa Island, southwestern Japan (26˚51’53.74”N, 128˚14’43.93”E. Fig. 1 ), c.a.
10 m
depth,
10 August 2016
, SCUBA diving, coll.
By Y.
Fujita.

5 February 2017

Diagnosis . Disc scales polygonal, uniform in size; oral shields almost as long as wide, shallow concave proximal sides that end in a fairly sharp point medially; arms about 9 times longer than disc diameter; 3 cylindrical arm spines, of which the oral most one is slightly larger than the other two.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Ophiozonella cavernalis
n. sp.
A, living status in situ, aboral view of RUMF-ZE-02008, RUMF-ZE-02009 or HD- 2017-15; B, anesthetized, aboral view of the holotype (RUMF-ZE-02008); C, D, SEM photos of a paratype (RUMF-ZE- 02009), aboral disc (C) and oral disc (D). Abbreviations: ASH, adoral shield; OP, oral plate; OS, oral shield; P, oral papillae; T, tooth.

subSubSection.paragraph: Arms. Five in number, 3 with evidence of regeneration, 31–37 mm in length, and 2 entire arms 41–46 mm in length, 1.6 mm wide and 1.2 mm high, arched on dorsal side and flat on ventral side. Arms tapering gradually toward the arm tip ( Fig. 9 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
Ophiozonella cavernalis
n. sp.
holotype (RUMF-ZE-02008). A, aboral disc; B, aboral peripheral disc and proximal portion of arm; C, aboral central disc; D, oral disc and proximal portion of arms; E, oral disc; F, interradial oral disc. Abbreviations: ASH, adoral shield; GS, genital slit; OP, oral plate; OS, oral shield; P, oral papillae; T, tooth.

subSubSection.paragraph: Color in life . Mottled light and dark brown on aboral disc, radial shields darker, arms variegated light brown with dark bands, a darker brown band on proximal portion of each arm spine ( Fig. 7 ).

Etymology . The specific name is derived from the Latin feminine noun,
cavernalis
meaning “inhabits cave”, referring to the cavernicolous habits of this new species.
Distribution . JAPAN : submarine caves on the Ryukyu Islands ( Okinawa and Ie Islands, Okinawa Island Group, and Shimoji Island, Miyako Island Group), 8–27 m depth ( Fig. 7A ).

Habitat . In the Ryukyu Islands, this new species was found in 4 submarine caves “Hedo-Dome cave” at Okinawa Island, “Dai-Dokutsu cave” and “unnamed cave” at Ie Island and “Akuma-no-Yakata cave” at Shimoji Island ( Fig. 1 ), and anchialine environment (low salinity and water-temperature) is confirmed in all caves. At the “Hedo-Dome cave”, this species was collected together with
Ophiolepis cavitata
n. sp.
( Fig. 7A ). At the “Dai- Dohkutsu cave”, this species is densely aggregated on the sandy-muddy bottom of the cave. This species was also found in similar environments (under rock on rubble zone or sandy-muddy bottom) in the “unnamed cave” and “Akuma-no-Yakata cave”. Compared to
Ophiolepis cavitata
n. sp.
, the number of
O . cavernalis
specimens is large and its presence in 4 caves suggest that it is indeed a cave endemic species with self-recruiting population.

Remarks . Among 31 species of
Ophiozonella
s. a., the present specimens are most closely related to
O. clypeata ( Lyman 1883 )
and partly agree with the original description in morphology ( Lyman, 1883 ). However,
O. cavernalis
n. sp.
can be distinguished from
O. clypeata
on the basis of the shape of oral shields and length of arm as follows:

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Ophiozonella cavernalis
n. sp.
holotype (RUMF-ZE-02008). A, aboral proximal portion of arm; B, aboral middle portion of arm; C, aboral distal tip of arm; D, oral proximal portion of arm; E, oral middle portion of arm; F, oral distal tip of arm; G, lateral middle portion of arm; H, lateral distal tip of arm. Arrow heads indicate tentacle scale. Abbreviation: ASP, arm spine; DAP, dorsal arm plate; LAP, lateral arm plate; VAP, ventral arm plate.

FIGURE 10.
Ophiozonella cavernalis
n. sp.
a paratype (RUMF-ZE-02009). SEM images of ossicles. A–C, dorsal arm plates, from proximal portion of arm, a square enlarged in B (A), and distal tip, an arrow head indicates a distal knob (B), and from distal portion of arm (C); D–G, lateral arm plates, from proximal portion of arms, outer view (D), inner view (E), distal view, a square enlarged in G (F), an arm spine articulation (G); H–K, lateral arm plates, from distal portion of arms, outer view (H), inner view (I), distal view, a square enlarged in K (J), an arm spine articulation (K); L, M, ventral arm plates, outer view from proximal portion (L) and inner view from distal portion (M) of arms. All lateral arm plates (D–K) are aligned in the same orientation. Orientations: ab, aboral side; dis, distal side; o, oral side; pro, proximal side. Abbreviations: DL, dorsal lobe; E, elevated structure; P, perforation; SA, spine articuration; SP, spur; VL, ventral lobe.

FIGURE 11.
Ophiozonella cavernalis
n. sp.
a paratype (RUMF-ZE-02009). SEM images of ossicles. A–E, vertebrae, from proximal portion of arms, proximal view (A), distal view (B), aboral view (C) and oral view (D), a square enlarged from D (E); F–H, vertebrae, from distal portion of arms, proximal view (F), distal view (G) and oral view (H); I–K, arm spines, from proximal portion of arms (I), distal portion of arms, inner (J) and outer (K) spines. Orientations: ab, aboral side; dis, distal side; o, oral side; pro, proximal. Abbreviations: AF, aboral muscle flange; D, depression for tentacle; OF, oral muscle flange; RWC, radial water canal; ST, secondary tooth.

subSubSection.paragraph:
(1) Oral shields. The oral shields of
O. cavernalis
n. sp.
are as long as wide, with slightly concave proximal sides that end in a fairly sharp point medially, whereas those of
O. clypeata
are 1.5 times longer than wide, blunt spear-head sharp, with acute proximal point ( Fig. 8E , Lyman 1883 ).

(2) Arms. Ratio of the longest entire arm to disc diameter is 9 times in
O. cavernalis
n. sp.
and at most 6 in
O. clypeata ( H. L. Clark, 1908 )
. For examination of other 18 paratypes , the smallest number of the ratio of the longest entire arm/disc diameter was 8 times.

In conjunction with the wide separation of their distribution (
O. cavernalis
n. sp.
is from 8–27 m , Japan and
O. clypeata
is from 158–559 m , Galapagos and Caribbean Sea), these two species should be distinguished as different species ( Lyman 1883 ; H. L. Clark 1917 ).

Three species of
Ophiozonella
s. str. ,
O. subtilis Koehler, 1922
,
O. insulata ( Lyman, 1878 )
and
O. casta ( Koehler, 1904 )
with more than 3 arm spines have been recorded from Indo-Pacific. These three species can be distinguished from
Ophiozonella cavernalis
n. sp.
mainly by the following characters:
Ophiozonella subtilis
has smaller and narrower oral shields;
O. insulate
and
O. casta
have approximately 15 and 10 disc scales on interradial oral surface, respectively, which are fewer than 30–50 scales of
O. cavernalis
( Lyman, 1878 ; Koehler, 1904 , 1922 ).
